Topic: Illustrate plants with and without water.
Level Description: Proficient (shows most elements clearly and correctly)
CAN: The student can draw a plant that is healthy, with clear signs of vitality such as green leaves and firm stems, indicating it has enough water to live and grow.
The student can draw a plant that is wilting, with drooping leaves and stems to show what happens when a plant does not get water.
The student can effectively present a side-by-side comparison of the same type of plant, one healthy with water and one wilting without, to demonstrate the effects of water supply on plant health.
The student might incorporate additional details like the sun to suggest that plants need more than just water, such as light, to survive.
CANNOT: The student may inconsistently include soil in the drawing or may not clearly convey its importance *(student focuses primarily on water)*.
The student might omit or inadequately depict non-water elements like sunlight or air, providing the impression that water is the only necessity *(student simplifies the needs of plants)*.
